CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in New Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 5, 1967, pg. 1 reads: "Wm. "Bouie" Haden - "Attack the Polls" Portion of accompanying article reads:  "Police Heads Back Advances, Race Amity - The Pittsburgh branch NAACP and  the United Negro Protest Committee met with Director of Public Safety David W. Craig here Tuesday and agreed on a 12-point program which will include a recruitment drive to bring more Negroes to the force..."Cutline and portion of article published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 5, 1967, pg. 1 reads: "Haden Makes New Demand: "Ballots For Bullets" Rights Militant Says "Act Now" - Plan Calls For Neighborhood Voter Registration Offices  - A Homewood-Brushton civil rights group has sounded a call for a new demand which may have far greater effect on the community than any other single civil rights program in Pittsburgh this year.  William "Bouie" Haden, militant leader of the United Movement for Progress, has called on City and County administrations to "trade ballots for bullets."image of William "Bouie" Haden published with other individuals and background masked.
TitMainTitle: Two unknown men, Reverend Jimmy Joe Robinson, William "Bouie" Haden, and Reverend Donald McIlvane, outside large church or city building
